fields.description:
While running an instance, I noticed that the wrong ramdisk was being used inside the instance.  After further investigation, the EMI (which was bundled with a different ERI and EKI than the Eucalyptus Loadbalancer) was registered with the ERI and EKI of the Eucalyptus Loadbalancer.

Below are the steps involving EMI registration, leading up to the actual bug seen in the instance.

* ERI and EKI used for registration
{code}
[root@odc-d-20 hspencer]# euca-describe-images eri-D289379D eki-4F963CF9
IMAGE	eki-4F963CF9	updated-centos5-kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.18-348.12.1.el5.manifest.xml	907289521555	available	private	x86_64	kernel				instance-store
IMAGE	eri-D289379D	new-centos5-ramdisk-kvm/initrd-2.6.18-348.12.1.el5.img.manifest.xml	907289521555	available	private	x86_64	ramdisk	
{code}

* EMI bundle, upload and registration
{code}
[root@odc-d-20 hspencer]# euca-bundle-image -i euca-centos5-2013.06.18-x86_64.img --ramdisk eri-D289379D --ramdisk eki-4F963CF9 -r x86_64

comments.body: [sosreport|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/secure/attachment/16446/sosreport-odc-d-20-20130809200046-4079.tar.xz] contains DB dump, eucalyptus logs, and additional system information.  Please let me know if more information is needed.

I changed the cloud logging from _INFO_ to _DEBUG_.  I was able to reproduce the issue, but didn't see anything in the logs that point to whats going on.

{code}
# euca-bundle-image -i euca-centos5-2013.06.18-x86_64.img --ramdisk eri-D289379D --ramdisk eki-4F963CF9 -r x86_64

# euca-register -n new-centos5-root new-centos5-root-v4/euca-centos5-2013.06.18-x86_64.img.manifest.xml

So from this, it looks like AWS keeps the image from being registered due to the double ramdisk option being passed. 

This does confirm however that ec2-bundle-image doesn't have any checks to make sure that the --ramdisk option is used only once.

[~hspencer] I hope this answers your questions.
{code}
The default kernel and Ramdisk are set in two ways:
1) When they are null and the first kernal and ramdisk are registered.
2) Manually in the admin GUI.

You can associate the kernal and ramdisk to an image in 3 ways:
1) euca-bundle-image
   a) if either the kernal or ramdisk is passed in with an incorrect prefix then both defaults are used
      (Harold this is what you are seeing)
   b) if two of the same parameter are passed in and they both have the correct prefix the second one is used. 
2) euca-run-instances
   a) if either the kernal or ramdisk is passed in with an incorrect prefix then and error is thrown
   b) if two of the same parameter are passed in and they both have the correct prefix the second one is used.   
3) if no valid kernal or ramdisk is associated on the first two ways the default is used for the undefined parameter.
{code}
